name: Probability tree diagrams with independent events 2

skills.name: Answer questions involving independent events expressed as fractions, where the result of just one path across a tree diagram needs to be calculated
Answer questions involving independent events expressed as decimals, where the result of just one path across a tree diagram needs to be calculated
Answer questions involving independent events expressed as fractions, where the result of more than one path across a tree diagram needs to be calculated
Answer questions involving independent events expressed as decimals, where the result of more than one path across a tree diagram needs to be calculated
Identify the branches that give the correct answer to a tree diagram question representing independent events

explanations.A: Not quite! You have found the probability of winning at both rather than losing at both.
explanations.B: Not quite! We need to take into account the probability of losing at both games, not just the second one.
explanations.C: Not quite! I think you have added the probabilities here. What do we do when we travel along a path in a tree diagram instead of adding?
explanations.D: The bottom path is the probability that they lose both and we always multiply along branches in a tree diagram, so the answer is 0.1 x 0.8 = 0.08.

explanations.A: Not quite! I think you have added the probabilities here. Remember, probabilities cannot take a value greater than 1. What do we do when we travel along a path in a tree diagram instead of adding?
explanations.B: Have another go. I think you have made a calculation error here.
explanations.C: The top path is the probability that they win both and we always multiply along branches in a tree diagram, so the answer is 0.6 x 0.7 = 0.42.
explanations.D: Almost! Have a check of your calculation again. Remember, probabilities cannot take a value greater than 1.

explanations.A: The relevant paths on the diagram are the second and third paths. The probability for path 2 (win then lose) is 0.9 x 0.8 = 0.72. The probability for path 3 (lose then win) is 0.1 x 0.2 = 0.02. Adding these together gives 0.74.
explanations.B: Not quite! I think you have multiplied the probabilities from the two possible routes. What should we do instead of multiplying at this stage?
explanations.C: Have another think. It looks like you have added all of the probabilities here, but what do we do when moving along the branches of a tree diagram? Remember, probabilities cannot be greater than 1.
explanations.D: Keep going! It looks like you have correctly calculated the probability of a win then loss, however there is another path that gives exactly one win that we need to take into account too.

explanations.A: Have another think. It looks like you have added all of the probabilities here, but what do we do when moving along the branches of a tree diagram? Remember, probabilities cannot be greater than 1.
explanations.B: Keep going! You have calculated the probability of only winning one game out of the two, but the question asked for AT LEAST one game out of the two. So what else do we need to include?
explanations.C: Have another think. We need to look for which paths through the tree diagram give us at least 1 win, and then add up the probabilities of each of these paths. This means we also need to think about what we do to calculate the probability along each relevant route of the tree diagram.
explanations.D: The relevant paths on the diagram are the first, second and third paths. The probability for path 1 (win then win) is 0.3 × 0.2 = 0.06. The probability for path 2 (win then lose) is 0.3 × 0.8 = 0.24. The probability for path 3 (lose then win) is 0.7 × 0.2 = 0.14. We then need to add these all together: 0.06 + 0.24 + 0.14 = 0.44.

explanations.A: The bottom path is the probability that they lose both and we always multiply along branches in a tree diagram, so the answer is 5/8 x 2/3 = 10/24
explanations.B: Have another think. What path do we need to follow to give us the outcome of losing both games? How do we combine these 2 probabilities?
explanations.C: Have another think. I can see you've placed the digits of the relevant fractions next to each other here, but have a think about how we multiply fractions.
explanations.D: Not quite! I can see you have added the numerators and added the denominators here, however this is not how we add fractions, and when we move along the branches we need to do a different operation to adding.

explanations.A: Have another think. I can see you've placed the digits of the relevant fractions next to each other here, but have a think about how we multiply fractions.
explanations.B: Not quite! You seem to have tried cross-multiplication here, which we can only do when our fractions are either side of an equals sign. Have a think how we multiply 2 fractions together.
explanations.C: Not quite! I can see you have added the numerators and added the denominators here, however this is not how we add fractions, and when we move along the branches we need to do a different operation to adding.
explanations.D: The top path is the probability that they win both and we always multiply along branches in a tree diagram, so the answer is: 2/7 × 7/9 = 14/63.

explanations.A: Not quite! I see you have added all of the relevant fractions here. Remember, probabilities cannot be greater than 1, so this answer doesn't make sense. What path(s) do we need to follow to give us the outcome of winning exactly one game? How do we combine these probabilities?
explanations.B: Paths 2 and 3 give us exactly one win. The probability from path 2 is 3/8 x 2/3 = 6/24 The probability from path 3 is 5/8 x 1/3 = 5/24. We then need to add them together. 6/24 + 5/24 = 11/24
explanations.C: Keep going! You have found the probability for path 2, however there is another path that gives an outcome of exactly 1 win that we need to include too.
explanations.D: Nearly! I think you have also included the probability of winning both games in your total, whereas the question asks for the probability of winning exactly one game only.

explanations.A: Paths 2 and 3 give us exactly one win. The probability from path 2 is 3/5 × 3/4 = 9/20 The probability from path 3 is 2/5 × 1/4 = 2/20. We then need to add them together: 9/20 + 2/20 = 11/20.
explanations.B: Nearly! I think you have also included the probability of winning both games in your total, whereas the question asks for the probability of winning exactly one game only.
explanations.C: Not quite! I see you have added all of the relevant fractions here. Remember, probabilities cannot be greater than 1, so this answer doesn't make sense. What path(s) do we need to follow to give us the outcome of winning exactly one game? How do we combine these probabilities?
explanations.D: Keep going! You have found the probability for path 2, however there is another path that gives an outcome of exactly 1 win that we need to include too.

explanations.A: Keep going! You have found one of the correct paths, but this isn't the only one.
explanations.B: In Path 1, we pick both red and in Path 4, we pick both black.
explanations.C: Not quite! Look at path 3 again, along this path we would pick black first, then red, which aren't the same colour.
explanations.D: Not quite! Look at paths 2 and 3 again, along these paths we would pick one counter of each colour, whereas the question asks for the paths where we pick the same colour both times.

explanations.C: In Path 1, we pick both red and in Path 4, we pick both black.
